abstract.p: Reports on prehistoric finds from caves at Rhagatt.

div.p: I returned from Rhagatt yesterday, after having had a most pleasant day at Cave-digging.

Mrs Lloyd entertained me en Prince, and on Friday organised a party to explore the cave and placed several workmen at my disposal. On reaching the place after a drive of 14 miles, I found that all the bones you sent me were discovered in a space between two limestone beds, where the intervening softer material had been carried away by water. Its maximum heighth was about 4 to 6 inches and its width 20 feet or more, and it extended parallel to the bedding of the rock

The bones had manifestly been conveyed in by water, and belonged to the Prehistoric epoch (which I have defined in a paper now in the press, that will be sent to you shortly). They were washed out of an old refuse-heap, which has now utterly disappeared.

At a little distance and much lower down in the rock there is a cave, full of red cave-earth, a kind of modern red silt, that I have found invariably to be barren of any prehistoric or postglacial remains. We dug into it and then forsook it for a spot that seemed to me to be likely to contain bones. Here we met with a curious jumble of human bones, and remains of horse, goat, hare, rabbit, badger, enormous birds, wolf, wild cat, fox and Celtic Shorthorn. In the small area excavated there were the remains of at least 5 corpses varying by age from infancy to the decline of life. All the adult teeth were ground smooth like the so called Ancient British teeth. The place that contained them was a small rock-shelter, gradually passing into a hole, which may perhaps be the entrance into a cave. We dug 6 feet into it, and Mrs Lloyd intends to carry the exploration on for her own satisfaction. The example set by M. Lartet in the Aurignac cave, prevents my hazarding a guess at the age of the human bones, or at the cause by which they were introduced. Most of the long-bones were perfect; the few that were imperfect were broken by the fall of stones from the roof. The perfection of the vertebræ implies also that neither dogs, nor wolves had gained access to the corpses to which they belong, since both those animals invariably eat the centra and most of the neural arches. div.note: After the discovery of cave bones on the Rhagatt estate near Corwen in Wales, CD, who was on vacation in Wales at the time, sent the bones to Dawkins for identification (see Correspondence vol. 17, letter to W. B. Dawkins, 19 July [1869], and letter to M. C. Lloyd, [24 July 1869]).
Gertrude Jane Mary Lloyd. CD evidently enclosed this letter in his letter to Mary Charlotte Lloyd of 4 August [1869] (Correspondence vol. 17).
Dawkins refers to his paper ‘The Denbighshire caves’ (Dawkins 1869).
For more on Lloyd’s exploration of the cave, see Correspondence vol. 17, letter from W. B. Dawkins, 19 October 1869. See also Lucas 2007, pp. 326–7.

In 1860, Edouard Lartet had discovered mammoth and cave-bear bones along with implements of stone and bone in a cave near Aurignac in southern France. Lartet was very cautious in dating the human occupancy of the cave, but concluded it probably pre-dated the diluvian period. (See Lartet 1862, p. 71.)
